questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient is told about the benefits and complications of hysterectomy and she agrees to the procedure. What kind of consent is this? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Informed consent

 

Informed consent is obtained when a patient is provided with comprehensive information about a medical procedure, including its benefits, risks, and possible complications, and then agrees to undergo the procedure. This ensures that the patient's decision is based on an understanding of all relevant information.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Implied consent: Implied consent is assumed when a patient visits a healthcare provider for a basic examination. It does not apply to invasive procedures like surgery.

 

Option C. Opt out: Opt-out consent is used when consent is presumed unless the individual actively declines. This is not applicable in the context of medical procedures requiring explicit consent.

 

Option D. Passive consent: Passive consent typically refers to situations where consent is inferred from a lack of objection. This is not applicable in medical contexts where explicit, informed consent is required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Consent can be classified in two ways:

 

1. Based on how the consent is given

 

 

2. Based on how much information provided:

questions.text: A patient got prick by rose thorn and after that there are linear lesions noted along the lymphatics. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sporotrichosis

 

The clinical presentation suggests lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis, a subcutaneous fungal infection caused by Sporothrix schenckii. This fungus is commonly found in soil, plants, and decaying vegetation, and rose thorn injury is a classic risk factor.

 

Features of Sporotrichosis:

 

  • Causative agent: Sporothrix schenckii (a dimorphic fungus).
  • Mode of infection: Traumatic implantation (e.g., rose thorn, gardening injury).
  • Clinical progression:
    • Initial painless papule or ulcer at the site of injury.
    • Spreads along the lymphatics, forming linear nodular lesions (sporotrichoid pattern).

 

 

  • Lesions ulcerate over time but remain relatively painless.

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • Culture (gold standard): S. schenckii grows as cigar-shaped yeast in tissue.
  • Histopathology: Granulomatous inflammation.
  • Direct microscopy: Asteroid bodies (yeast cells surrounded by eosinophilic material).

 

Treatment:

 

  • First-line therapy: Itraconazole (for cutaneous and lymphocutaneous forms).
  • Severe/systemic cases: Amphotericin B.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chromoblastomycosis

 

  • Develops verrucous lesion at site of thorn prick

 

 

  • Caused by dematiaceous fungi
  • Shows copper penny bodies on KOH mount

 

 

  • Localized lesion without lymphatic spread

 

Option C. Tinea corporis

 

  • Superficial dermatophyte infection of glabrous skin
  • Shows annular plaque with active borders 

 

 

  • No relation to thorn prick
  • No lymphatic spread

 

Option D. Mycetoma

 

  • Shows classic triad after thorn prick: 
    • Granules
    • Sinuses
    • Swelling

 

 

  • No linear spread along lymphatics
  • More localized presentation
  • Can be caused by bacteria or fungi

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sporotrichosis should be suspected in patients with a history of rose thorn injury and linear nodular lesions along lymphatics. It is treated with itraconazole.

questions.text: Banana sign and lemon sign are seen in? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NTD

 

Banana sign and lemon sign are ultrasound findings typically associated with neural tube defects (NTD), more specifically spina bifida.

 

  • Banana sign: This refers to the excessive curvature of the cerebellum, which appears compressed and curved, resembling a banana.
  • Lemon sign: This is characterized by the pinching of the frontal bones of the fetal skull, causing it to appear like a lemon when viewed from the front. These signs are indicative of the changes in intracranial pressure and structure caused by spina bifida.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anencephaly: This condition involves the absence of a major portion of the brain, skull, and scalp, and is often described as having a "frog-like" face due to the absence of the cranial vault.

 

Option C. Down syndrome: Down syndrome has various ultrasound markers, but these are typically subtle and referred to as soft tissue markers, not including the banana or lemon signs.

 

Option D. Duodenal atresia: This condition is characterized by the "double bubble" sign on ultrasound, indicating a blockage in the duodenum, and is not associated with the banana or lemon signs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Banana sign and lemon sign are ultrasound findings seen in neural tube defects (NTD), particularly in cases of spina bifida.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a-3, b-1, c-4, d-2

 

A-3. Rotavirus is a member of the Reoviridae family, which is an exception among RNA viruses because it has double-stranded RNA (dsRNA).

 

B-1. SARS-CoV-2 is a coronavirus, which is a single-stranded RNA (ssRNA) virus.

 

C-4. Parvovirus is a unique DNA virus because it has single-stranded DNA (ssDNA).

 

D-2. HPV (Human Papillomavirus) belongs to the Papillomaviridae family and has double-stranded DNA (dsDNA).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the nucleic acid composition of viruses is crucial. Rotavirus has dsRNA, SARS-CoV-2 has ssRNA, Parvovirus has ssDNA, and HPV has dsDNA.

questions.text: From which pharyngeal pouch does the crypta magna develop?(NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2nd

 

Explanation:

 

Crypta magna is part of the palatine tonsil which develops from the epithelial lining of the second pharyngeal pouch. The second pouch contributes significantly to the formation of the tonsils, with the crypta magna being a notable structure within them. This correlates with the broader role of the second pouch in contributing to the immune system via the development of tonsillar tissues.

 

 

Other Options:

 

  • a. 1st: Incorrect as the first pouch develops into the epithelial lining of the auditory tube and middle ear cavity.
  • c. 3rd: Incorrect as it contributes to the development of the thymus and inferior parathyroid glands.
  • d. 4th: Incorrect as it forms the superior parathyroid glands and the ultimobranchial body.

 

Educational objective:

 

The crypta magna, a part of the palatine tonsil, develops from the epithelial lining of the second pharyngeal pouch.

questions.text: Injury to which of the following structures will result in decreased lacrimal secretion? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Answer: D. Pterygopalatine ganglion

 

Pterygopalatine ganglion is a parasympathetic ganglion associated with the secretomotor pathway of the lacrimal gland. The secretomotor pathway for the lacrimal gland begins at the superior salivatory nucleus in the brainstem, travels via the facial nerve (CN VII) and continues as the greater petrosal nerve. This nerve joins with the deep petrosal nerve in the pterygoid canal to form the nerve of pterygoid canal (Vidian's nerve), which synapses in the pterygopalatine ganglion. Postganglionic fibers then travel with the maxillary nerve to the zygomatic nerve, and then via the zygomaticotemporal nerve to join the lacrimal nerve, ultimately supplying the lacrimal gland and causing lacrimation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parotid nerve - This is not a standard anatomical term. The parotid gland receives parasympathetic innervation via the otic ganglion through the auriculotemporal nerve, not the lacrimal gland.

 

Option B. Gasserian ganglion - This is the trigeminal ganglion which contains cell bodies of sensory neurons of the trigeminal nerve (CN V). While it's related to the lacrimal nerve (via V1), it doesn't contain parasympathetic fibers for lacrimal secretion.

 

Option C. Ciliary ganglion - This parasympathetic ganglion is associated with CN III and controls pupillary constriction and accommodation. It's not involved in the secretomotor pathway for the lacrimal gland.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The secretomotor pathway for the lacrimal gland follows the course: superior salivatory nucleus → facial nerve → greater petrosal nerve → nerve of pterygoid canal → pterygopalatine ganglion → maxillary nerve → zygomatic nerve → zygomaticotemporal nerve → lacrimal nerve → lacrimal gland.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used for diagnosing suspected lateral sinus thrombosis? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laugier’s Sign

 

Explanation:

 

Laugier's sign is not used for diagnosing lateral sinus thrombosis. It is actually a sign associated with fracture of the zygomatic arch, where tenderness is elicited on pressing the fractured fragments. This sign has no relationship to lateral sinus thrombosis or any other otological condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Queckenstedt's Test: This is correctly associated with lateral sinus thrombosis diagnosis. Also called the Tobey-Ayer test, it involves compression of the jugular vein while monitoring CSF pressure via lumbar puncture. In lateral sinus thrombosis, compression of the affected side's jugular vein causes no change in CSF pressure, while compression of the normal side increases CSF pressure.

 

Option B. Crowe-Beck Test: This is correctly used for diagnosing lateral sinus thrombosis. It is an alternative to Queckenstedt's test that avoids lumbar puncture. It involves observing retinal vein engorgement through fundoscopy during jugular compression. With lateral sinus thrombosis, compression of the affected side causes no retinal vein engorgement, while compression of the normal side does.

 

Option C. Griesinger's Sign: This is correctly associated with lateral sinus thrombosis. It refers to edema and tenderness over the mastoid emissary vein (posterior to the mastoid process), which occurs due to thrombophlebitis extending from the lateral sinus to the emissary vein.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While Queckenstedt's test, Crowe-Beck test, and Griesinger's sign are all valid diagnostic indicators for lateral sinus thrombosis, Laugier's sign is unrelated and specifically associated with zygomatic arch fractures.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an inherited cause of thrombosis? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PNH (Paroxysmal Nocturnal Haemoglobinuria)

 

PNH is an acquired disorder, not inherited. It occurs due to acquired mutations in myeloid stem cells affecting the PIGA gene. This leads to deficiency of CD55 and CD59 proteins that normally protect cells from complement-mediated destruction. 

 

The condition is characterized by intravascular hemolysis, thrombosis (particularly in unusual sites like hepatic veins causing Budd-Chiari syndrome), and pancytopenia.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Protein S deficiency: Incorrect because it is an inherited thrombophilic condition. Protein S acts as a cofactor for Protein C and helps prevent excessive clotting.

 

Option B. Homocystinuria: Incorrect because it is an inherited metabolic disorder that causes elevated homocysteine levels, leading to increased risk of thrombosis.

 

Option D. AT III deficiency: Incorrect because Antithrombin III deficiency is an inherited condition that increases risk of thrombosis by reducing the ability to inhibit activated clotting factors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PNH is an acquired disorder caused by somatic mutations, while Protein S deficiency, Homocystinuria, and AT III deficiency are inherited causes of thrombosis.

questions.text: A young girl presents with retention of urine and cyclical abdominal pain. On examination, there is a tense bluish bulge seen at the introitus. The diagnosis is? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Imperforate hymen

 

An imperforate hymen is a congenital disorder where the hymen, a thin membrane that typically surrounds or partially covers the vaginal opening, completely obstructs the vaginal opening. This condition can lead to the accumulation of menstrual blood within the vagina (hematocolpos) and uterus (hematometra), resulting in cyclical abdominal pain and urinary retention due to pressure on the bladder.

 

The classic presentation includes:

 

  • Cyclical abdominal pain: This occurs as menstrual blood accumulates but cannot exit the body, leading to distension and discomfort.
  • Retention of urine: The accumulated blood can exert pressure on the bladder and urethra, causing difficulty in urination.
  • Tense bluish bulge at the introitus: This is a distinctive finding in imperforate hymen, where the accumulated blood stretches the hymen, causing it to appear bluish and bulging at the vaginal opening.

 

The treatment for an imperforate hymen typically involves making a cruciate incision in the hymen to drain the accumulated blood (hematocolpos) and relieve the symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transverse vaginal septum: This condition involves a fibrous or muscular wall across the vagina, which can also cause symptoms similar to an imperforate hymen, such as hematocolpos and urinary retention. However, it does not usually present with the characteristic tense bluish bulge at the introitus because the septum is thicker and the blood does not push against the hymen.

 

Option C. Vertical vaginal septum: A vertical vaginal septum is a partition that divides the vaginal canal into two parts. While it may lead to reproductive issues or dyspareunia, it typically does not cause urinary retention or cyclical pain as described in this case, nor does it present with a bluish bulge.

 

Option D. Mullerian agenesis: This is a congenital absence of the uterus, cervix, and upper part of the vagina. Patients with this condition often present with primary amenorrhea but do not typically have cyclical abdominal pain or urinary retention. Additionally, there would be no bluish bulge at the introitus because there is no accumulation of blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of cyclical abdominal pain, urinary retention, and a tense bluish bulge at the introitus in a young girl strongly suggests an imperforate hymen. Early diagnosis and surgical intervention can prevent complications and relieve symptoms.

questions.text: A patient presents with post-auricular numbness and a thickened cord-like structure in the cervical region. Identify the most likely structure involved: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Greater auricular nerve

 

The greater auricular nerve (C2, C3) branch of the cervical plexus is the most likely structure involved in this case. The symptoms described - post-auricular numbness and a thickened cord-like structure - are characteristic of great auricular nerve involvement. This nerve has two important divisions:

 

  • Anterior division: supplies the angle of the mandible (shaving area)
  • Posterior division: supplies the auricle (pinna) The nerve runs towards the ear/pinna and is responsible for sensory innervation of this region. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. External jugular vein: Incorrect. This vein is located superficially in the cervical region, but its pathology, such as thrombosis, typically presents with redness, swelling, and engorgement. 

 

Option B. Cervical lymph nodes: Incorrect. Enlarged or inflamed lymph nodes are usually nodular and can cause tenderness but not numbness unless compressing a nearby nerve. 

 

Option C. Superficial thrombophlebitis: Incorrect. This condition involves inflammation of superficial veins and is characterized by redness, pain, and warmth along the course of the vein. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The greater auricular nerve (C2, C3) provides sensory innervation to the skin over the parotid region, auricle, and angle of the mandible. Lesions or compression of this nerve can lead to post-auricular numbness and symptoms along its anatomical path.

choices.text: Free iron is toxic for the cells
Iron will be stored in the form of transferrin
Iron is transported via Apoferritin in the blood
Hepcidin enhances iron transport through Ferroportin

questions.text: Which one of the following is correct about iron transport? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Free iron is toxic for the cells

 

Free iron in the body is highly reactive and can catalyze the formation of free radicals, leading to oxidative stress and cellular damage. This is why iron is typically bound to proteins such as transferrin in the blood and ferritin within cells to prevent free iron from causing harm. The body has mechanisms to tightly regulate iron levels to avoid toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Iron will be stored in the form of transferrin: This statement is incorrect. Transferrin is a transport protein that carries iron in the bloodstream. Iron is stored in the body as ferritin or hemosiderin, not transferrin.

 

Option C. Iron is transported via Apoferritin in the blood: This is incorrect. Apoferritin binds iron to form ferritin, which is used for storage, not transport. Iron transport in the blood is mainly handled by transferrin.

 

Option D. Hepcidin enhances iron transport through Ferroportin: This is incorrect. Hepcidin actually inhibits iron transport by binding to ferroportin, leading to its degradation. This reduces the amount of iron released into the bloodstream from cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Free iron is toxic to cells due to its ability to generate reactive oxygen species, which can cause significant cellular damage.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with persistent nasal congestion, foul-smelling greenish-black nasal crusts, and anosmia. Examination reveals a dry nasal cavity with crust formation. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atrophic rhinitis

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests atrophic rhinitis. 

 

  • The presence of foul-smelling greenish-black discharge (due to Klebsiella ozaenae infection)
  • Anosmia (due to atrophy of nerve elements)
  • Crusting in nasal cavity (due to transformation of normal ciliated columnar epithelium to abnormal stratified squamous epithelium)
  • Female patient (consistent with demographics as atrophic rhinitis commonly affects females)
  • The disease process involves atrophy of nasal mucosa, leading to loss of defense mechanisms (cilia and mucous glands), resulting in secondary infections and crust formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rhinoscleroma

 

  • While the first stage can mimic atrophic rhinitis, it typically doesn't present with anosmia
  • Characterized by painless nodules giving woody feel ("woody nose" or "hebra nose")
  • Caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis

 

 

Option C. Hypertrophic rhinitis

 

  • Presents with bilateral inferior turbinate hypertrophy
  • Shows mulberry appearance of turbinates
  • No crusting or anosmia

 

Option D. Allergic rhinitis

 

  • Presents with sneezing, itching, and watery discharge
  • IgE-mediated type 1 hypersensitivity reaction
  • No foul smell or crusting
  • Typically shows pale, boggy mucosa

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrophic Rhinitis (Ozaenae)

questions.text: In a patient with lipoprotein lipase deficiency, which of the following is increased following a fatty meal? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chylomicron

 

Chylomicron levels are increased following a fatty meal in individuals with lipoprotein lipase deficiency. Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) is responsible for breaking down triglycerides in chylomicrons. In its absence, chylomicrons accumulate in the bloodstream, leading to elevated chylomicron levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. LDL: LDL (Low-Density Lipoprotein) levels may be elevated as well in individuals with lipoprotein lipase deficiency, but this increase is primarily associated with genetic factors and not directly related to a fatty meal.

 

Option C. HDL: HDL (High-Density Lipoprotein) levels are typically not significantly affected by lipoprotein lipase deficiency.

 

Option D. Apo A: Apolipoprotein A (Apo A) is a component of HDL and is not directly increased following a fatty meal in individuals with lipoprotein lipase deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frederickson’s classification of hyperlipoproteinemia

questions.text: A child presents with acute respiratory distress. On examination, the abdomen was scaphoid. Which of the  following should not be performed in this patient : (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bag and mask ventilation

 

Explanation:

 

Bag and mask ventilation is typically the first step in managing respiratory distress to provide support. However, in the case of a scaphoid abdomen, which suggests the possibility of a congenital diaphragmatic hernia, this method can be dangerous. It could inflate the stomach and intestines, which may be in the thoracic cavity, thus reducing lung volume further and potentially worsening respiratory distress. Therefore, bag and mask ventilation should be avoided in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PPV with ETT: Although this can be cautiously used, it should be carefully monitored due to the risk of increasing thoracic pressure.

 

Option C. Oxygen therapy: This is a safe method to improve oxygenation without the risks associated with positive pressure ventilation.

 

Option D. Intubation: This is necessary for securing the airway and providing ventilatory support in severe respiratory distress and is safer compared to bag and mask ventilation in the context of a suspected diaphragmatic hernia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bag and mask ventilation should be avoided in a child with acute respiratory distress and a scaphoid abdomen, as it may exacerbate the condition if a congenital diaphragmatic hernia is present.

questions.text: A 32-year-old healthcare worker presents with fatigue, low-grade fever, and mild right upper quadrant discomfort for the past 2 weeks. He reports a needlestick injury 3 months ago while drawing blood from a patient with unknown hepatitis status. Physical examination reveals mild icterus and tender hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigations show elevated ALT and AST levels. Serological testing shows the presence of HBsAg and IgM anti-HBc. What does the presence of IgM anti-HBc indicate? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute infection

 

IgM anti-HBc indicates acute hepatitis B infection. The presence of IgM antibodies generally indicates recent or ongoing infection in any disease, and hepatitis B is no exception. When combined with elevated liver enzymes (ALT and AST) and HBsAg, this pattern is diagnostic of acute hepatitis B infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carrier: Carriers typically have HBsAg but negative IgM anti-HBc.

 

Option B. Chronic infection: Chronic infection is characterized by HBsAg persistence and IgG (not IgM) anti-HBc.

 

Option D. Supercarrier: This is not a standard medical term in hepatitis B infection classification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IgM anti-HBc is the key serological marker for diagnosing acute hepatitis B infection, especially when accompanied by HBsAg and elevated liver enzymes.

questions.text: All of the following are associated with good prognosis in schizophrenia, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Predominant Negative symptoms

 

Explanation: Predominant negative symptoms are associated with poor prognosis in schizophrenia, not good prognosis. Negative symptoms (often remembered as the "6As") include avolition (loss of drive), apathy (lack of concern), anhedonia (loss of pleasure), asociality (lack of social interaction), affective flattening (lack of emotional response), and alogia (decreased verbal communication). These symptoms respond poorly to medications and are considered poor prognostic factors.

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. Late onset (Incorrect): Advanced age of onset (>35 years) is associated with better prognosis in schizophrenia. Early onset (<20 years) is linked to poorer outcomes.
  • Option B. Presence of Depression (Incorrect): The presence of affective symptoms, including depression, is associated with better prognosis in schizophrenia.
  • Option D. Acute onset (Incorrect): Acute or abrupt onset of symptoms is associated with better prognosis compared to insidious onset.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Good prognostic factors in schizophrenia include acute/abrupt onset, later age of onset (>35 years), female gender, presence of affective symptoms, and predominant positive symptoms. Poor prognostic factors include insidious onset, early onset (<20 years), male gender, predominant negative symptoms, and absence of affective symptoms.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child with a history of GTCS presented with 4-5 episodes of seizures, and seizures are present for more than 45 minutes. What will be the most appropriate management for this patient?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lorazepam followed by levetiracetam

 

Explanation:

 

In the management of status epilepticus (SE), the first line of treatment involves benzodiazepines. Lorazepam is preferred due to its rapid onset and longer duration of action compared to other benzodiazepines like diazepam or midazolam.

 

  • First line treatment: Intravenous (IV) lorazepam (standard dose of 4 mg in adults; different doses for children).
  • If seizures persist after the first dose of lorazepam, it can be repeated once.
  • Second line treatment: If seizures continue after two doses of lorazepam, IV anti-epileptic drugs (AEDs) are administered. Options include IV phenytoin, fosphenytoin, levetiracetam, valproate, or lacosamide.
  • If still persist, intubate the patient, continuous EEG monitoring and give IV General anaesthesia (IV midazolam or IV propofol infusion)

 

In this case, following lorazepam with levetiracetam is consistent with current guidelines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Levetiracetam followed by valproate: Levetiracetam is a second-line treatment, not first-line.

 

Option C. Carbamazepine followed by lorazepam: Carbamazepine is not typically used in the acute management of SE.

 

Option D. Valproate followed by gabapentin: Valproate can be used as a second-line treatment, but gabapentin is not typically used for SE management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first line of management for status epilepticus is IV lorazepam, followed by IV antiepileptic drugs like levetiracetam if seizures persist.

questions.text: What is the most accurate description of Eczema marginatum? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tinea cruris

 

  • Eczema marginatum is another name for Tinea cruris, which is a dermatophyte infection of the groin area. 

 

 

  • It is also colloquially referred to as "jock itch" or "dhobi itch."
  • Tinea cruris presents as an annular, sharply demarcated plaque with peripheral scaling, inner aspects of the thighs. 
  • The infection expands centrifugally with central clearing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tinea capitis:

 

  • Tinea capitis refers to a dermatophyte infection of the scalp and hair, not the groin. 
  • It typically manifests as patches of hair loss with scaling and can present as black dot, gray patch, kerion, or favus variants depending on the causative organism and host immune response.

 

Option B. Tinea barbae: 

 

  • Tinea barbae refers to a fungal infection of the beard area in men. 
  • It is not the same as Eczema marginatum, which affects the groin area. 
  • Tinea barbae involves the coarse terminal hair of the beard and can cause follicular inflammation.

 

 

Option D. Tinea unguium:

 

  • Tinea unguium refers to a dermatophyte infection of the nail plate. 

 

 

  • It presents with discoloration, thickening, and crumbling of the nail plate with subungual hyperkeratosis. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Eczema marginatum is synonymous with Tinea cruris (fungal infection of the groin), characterized by annular, well-demarcated plaques with active margins showing scaling and inflammation, most commonly affecting the inner thighs and groin area.

questions.text:
Which of the following contributes to the latent period in a single muscle twitch? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Excitation-contraction coupling
  2. Opening of sodium channels on NMJ
  3. Transmission of impulse from the site of stimulus to NMJ
  4. Pumping of calcium back to the sarcoplasmic reticulum
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a, b, c

 

The latent period in a single muscle twitch refers to the time delay between the application of stimulus and the beginning of muscle contraction. This period represents several physiological processes that must occur sequentially before the muscle begins to contract.

 

a) Excitation-contraction coupling is a major component of the latent period. It involves the process by which an electrical stimulus (action potential) is converted into a mechanical response (muscle contraction). This includes the action potential reaching T-tubules, activation of dihydropyridine (DHP) receptors, mechanical attachment of T-tubule with L-tubule, opening of ryanodine receptor (RyR) channels, release of Ca²⁺ from sarcoplasmic reticulum, formation of calcium-troponin complex, and displacement of tropomyosin to allow actin-myosin cross-bridge formation.

 

b) Opening of sodium channels at the neuromuscular junction is also part of the latent period. When acetylcholine binds to nicotinic receptors at the motor end plate, it leads to the opening of ligand-gated Na⁺ channels, which generates an action potential in the muscle fiber.

 

c) Transmission of impulse from the site of stimulus to the neuromuscular junction contributes to the latent period as well. This involves the time taken for the action potential to propagate along the nerve fiber from the point of stimulation to the neuromuscular junction.

 

Other Option:

 

d) Pumping of calcium back to the sarcoplasmic reticulum is part of the relaxation phase of muscle contraction, not the latent period. This process occurs after the contraction has already begun and is responsible for muscle relaxation when Ca²⁺ is removed from the sarcoplasm by the SERCA pump (Sarco/Endoplasmic Reticulum Ca²⁺-ATPase).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The latent period in a single muscle twitch includes excitation-contraction coupling, opening of sodium channels at the neuromuscular junction, and transmission of impulse from the site of stimulus to the neuromuscular junction, but does not include calcium reuptake which is part of the relaxation phase.

questions.text:
Which of the following are the classical markers of a seminoma: (INICET NOV 2023)

 

  1. KIT    
  2. OCT 3
  3. PLAP
  4. HCG
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2 and 3

 

The classical markers of a seminoma include KIT (CD117), OCT 3 (also known as OCT3/4), and PLAP (Placental Alkaline Phosphatase). These markers are commonly used in the diagnosis and characterization of seminomas due to their high specificity.

 

1. KIT (CD117): A receptor tyrosine kinase that is strongly expressed in seminomas, aiding in differentiation from other testicular neoplasms.

 

2. OCT 3 (OCT3/4): A transcription factor essential for maintaining the pluripotency of germ cells and expressed in seminomas, reflecting their embryonal origin.

 

3. PLAP (Placental Alkaline Phosphatase): Frequently elevated in seminomas, this enzyme helps in confirming the germ cell origin of the tumor.

 

Other Options:

 

4. HCG (Human Chorionic Gonadotropin): Although some seminomas may express low levels of HCG, it is not considered a classical marker like the others, being more indicative of non-seminomatous germ cell tumors.

 

HCG may be present in ~15–20% of seminomas. However it is a classical marker for Choriocarcinoma (produced by syncytiotrophoblastic cells)

 

Therefore, some seminomas can elevate serum hCG

 

However:

 

  • Not seen in all seminoma
  • More characteristic of choriocarcinoma and mixed germ cell tumors

 

Educational objective:

 

When diagnosing seminoma, clinicians should primarily focus on markers KIT, OCT3/4, and PLAP due to their high specificity and relevance to the germ cell lineage. HCG, although sometimes present, is not a classical marker for seminoma.

questions.text: An investigation was conducted to evaluate the nutritional status of young children residing in both rural and urban regions. Among the participants, 30 children from rural areas and 20 children from urban areas were found to be malnourished. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Chi Square test

 

The Chi Square test can be used to determine whether there is a significant association or relationship between two categorical variables. In this case, the two variables are the nutritional status (malnourished or not malnourished) and the location (rural or urban), both of which are Qualitative characters.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paired T test:  is used when comparing the means of two related samples, such as before and after measurements for the same group.

 

Option C. Standard error of the mean:  is a measure of the variability of sample means.

 

Option D.  ANOVA:  is used to compare the means of three or more groups.

These tests are not appropriate for analyzing the relationship between two categorical variables as in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Chi Square test is the appropriate statistical test for evaluating the association between two categorical variables, such as nutritional status (malnourished vs. not malnourished) and location (rural vs. urban).

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, cough, weight loss, histology of the pathology is as shown below. What is the most likely cytokine involved? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Interferon gamma

 

  • IFN-γ is crucial in the immune response against intracellular pathogens, including the activation of macrophages and the formation of granulomas, as seen in tuberculosis and other granulomatous diseases. It is produced primarily by T-helper cells (Th1) and is critical for orchestrating the cellular immune response that results in the granuloma formation evident in the provided histology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Complement 5a protein: Involved in the inflammatory process, enhancing the immune response by attracting immune cells to sites of infection, but not directly involved in granuloma formation.

 

Option C. Histamine: A mediator in allergic reactions, involved in vasodilation and increased vascular permeability, not typically associated with chronic inflammatory or granulomatous responses.

 

Option D. Prostaglandin: These are lipid compounds that mediate inflammation. Like histamine, they are more often associated with immediate inflammatory responses and pain, rather than chronic inflammation or granuloma formation.

 

Educational objective:

 

Interferon gamma is key in managing intracellular infections and is responsible for the activation of macrophages and other immune cells that culminate in granuloma formation, a central feature in controlling persistent pathogens such as those seen in tuberculosis.

questions.text: National Deworming Day is observed on:(FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 10 February and 10 August

 

National Deworming Day is observed on 10th February, with a repeat round conducted after six months on 10th August. During this program, albendazole is used for deworming. In many states, the 10th date of every month is observed as national deworming day, but the main nationwide observance is on these two dates.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

National Deworming Day is observed on 10th February with a repeat round after 6 months on 10th August, using albendazole for deworming.

questions.text: Which condition is characterized by flaccid bullae with mucosal involvement and intraepidermal acantholysis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pemphigus Vulgaris

 

  • Pemphigus vulgaris is an immunobullous disorder characterized by flaccid bullae that rapidly rupture to form painful erosions with slow healing. 

 

 

  • It shows a suprabasal intraepidermal split with acantholysis (separation of viable epidermal cells from each other) due to IgG autoantibodies against desmoglein-3 and desmoglein-1. 
  • Mucosal involvement is universal (95% of cases), with oral mucosa most frequently affected, presenting as painful erosions. 

 

 

  • The Nikolsky sign is positive due to acantholysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pemphigus Foliaceus: 

 

  • Though it's also an intraepidermal immunobullous disorder, it shows subcorneal split (more superficial than PV) with acantholysis due to antibodies against only desmoglein-1. Importantly, mucosal lesions are absent, and it primarily affects seborrheic areas (chest, scalp). 
  • Bullae are transient and superficial, usually manifesting as scaling and crusting.

 

 

Option C. Pemphigus Erythematosus: 

 

  • This is a less severe variant of pemphigus foliaceus characterized by dry, hyperkeratotic, scaly lesions, particularly affecting the malar region of the face. 

 

 

  • Like pemphigus foliaceus, mucosal involvement is absent.

 

Option D. Bullous Pemphigoid: 

 

  • Unlike pemphigus, bullous pemphigoid shows a subepidermal split (not intraepidermal) with tense rather than flaccid bullae. 

 

 

  • It targets basement membrane proteins (BPAG 1 and 2), not desmosomal proteins. 
  • Mucosal involvement occurs in only 10-30% of cases, and there's no acantholysis. 
  • The Nikolsky sign is negative.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Pemphigus vulgaris is uniquely characterized by the triad of flaccid bullae, universal mucosal involvement, and suprabasal acantholysis due to anti-desmoglein 3 antibodies, distinguishing it from other vesiculobullous disorders.

questions.text: The cranial part of the accessory nerve supplies which of the following muscles? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Superior constrictor

 

The cranial part of accessory nerve (CN XI) has a distinctive distribution pattern where it joins the vagus nerve (CN X) after both exit through the jugular foramen. After joining the vagus nerve, the cranial part of accessory nerve contributes fibers that are distributed with the pharyngeal branch of vagus nerve to supply 5 out of 6 pharyngeal muscles, including the superior constrictor muscle. It also supplies 4 out of 5 palatal muscles and all intrinsic muscles of the larynx. This unique pattern where the cranial root joins the vagus for distribution is important for understanding pharyngeal innervation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sternocleidomastoid - This muscle is supplied by the spinal part of the accessory nerve, not the cranial part. The spinal root emerges from the lateral aspect of the spinal cord, enters the cranium through foramen magnum, and then exits through jugular foramen.

 

Option B. Trapezius - Like the sternocleidomastoid, trapezius is also supplied by the spinal part of accessory nerve, not the cranial part. The spinal accessory component provides motor innervation to this muscle.

 

Option D. Stylopharyngeus - This is the only pharyngeal muscle not supplied by the cranial part of accessory nerve. It is uniquely innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX).

 

Educational Objective: The cranial part of accessory nerve joins the vagus nerve and supplies most pharyngeal muscles (5 out of 6) including the superior constrictor, while the spinal part independently supplies the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.
